title: Change in vectors for hanging balloons

content.question: Two negatively charged balloons are suspended from the ceiling by insulating strings, as shown in figure 1. Free-body diagrams showing the tension force <math alttext="F sub T" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>T</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> , electric force <math alttext="F sub E" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>E</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> , and gravitational force <math alttext="F sub g" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mrow><msub><mrow><mi>F</mi></mrow><mrow><mi>g</mi></mrow></msub></mrow></mrow></mstyle></math> on each balloon are shown in figure 2. If the amount of negative charge on each balloon increases, how should the length of the vectors shown in the figure be changed?

choices.label: Only the electric force vector should be longer, and the tension and gravitational force vectors should remain the same.
The electric and tension force vectors should be longer, and the gravitational force vector should remain the same.
All three force vectors should remain the same.
All three force vectors should be longer.

content.answer: The electric and tension force vectors should be longer, and the gravitational force vector should remain the same.

skill.text: 2.C: Compare physical quantities between two or more scenarios or at different times and locations in a single scenario.
